nodes.text: K-nearest neighbors (KNN) algorithm can be used to accurately predict the presence of heart disease from clinical and demographic patient data
Heart disease is a leading cause of death and early detection through predictive models can enable prevention and timely intervention
The proposed methodology applies KNN as a non-parametric, instance-based classifier using distance metrics to assign class labels based on majority vote of K neighbors
Data preprocessing steps include feature selection, handling imbalanced data via weighting strategies, and scaling prior to applying KNN

Related work shows multiple ML methods (KNN, SVM, decision trees, neural nets, ensembles) have been applied to heart disease prediction with reported high accuracies (example: SVM 92.3%, decision tree 93.19%)
Predictive models using clinical features (age, sex, cholesterol, blood pressure, ECG readings, thalassemia status, etc.) provide the input variables for heart disease classification
Implementation details: modelling repeated three times (repeats = 3), K set to 10 for experiments, and Euclidean distance used as distance metric
Model evaluation used cross-validation and metrics including sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, and AUC-ROC to assess classifier performance
K preference affects performance: odd K to avoid ties, small K risks overfitting, large K can introduce noise
Feature selection and class-weighting for imbalance are applied to improve predictive accuracy and address dataset noise

Dataset attribute definitions include age, sex, chest pain type, resting blood pressure, cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, rest ECG, max heart rate, exercise-induced angina, oldpeak, slope, ca, thal, and target label
Euclidean distance formula applied to compute neighbor distances and derive KNN classifier scores across different K values

Empirical results: histogram visualizations performed, male patients showed higher counts of diagnosed heart disease, and KNN produced performance results summarized by confusion matrix and other metrics
Confusion matrix based accuracy computed as ((38+45)/(38+10+7+45))*100 = 83%, indicating the KNN model achieved 83% accuracy on the reported test
Authors report that KNN yields promising high accuracy and AUC-ROC values and that feature importance analysis improves interpretability by identifying key risk factors

Conclusion: KNN is a simple, adaptable, and effective tool for heart disease prediction that can aid risk assessment and early detection, though it has limitations like computational cost and sensitivity to K and preprocessing
